Intro.0: A new technique that leverages Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) could allow attackers to bypass security solutions installed in the user’s system.
Intro.1: A rundown of the latest wave of threats targeting Linux systems.
Intro.2: Mumblehard, a botnet that targets servers running Linux has been shut down a year after it was first discovered.
Intro.3: The Linux Mint website has been hacked and was found to be pointing to malicious ISOs that contained an IRC bot. What happened and who is affected?
Intro.4: Moscow-based Kaspersky Lab this week launched Kaspersky Linux Mail Security, a new protection offering to help Linux-based mail servers combat spam and block malicious attachments.  [Read More]
Intro.5: A recently discovered malware family written using the Golang (Go) programming language is targeting Linux servers and uses a different binary for each attack, Talos warns.  [Read More]
Intro.6: A new Windows 10 feature that makes the popular Linux bash terminal available for Microsoft’s operating system could allow for more malware families to target the operating system, Check Point researchers claim.  [Read More]
Intro.7: A new Windows backdoor was apparently created by the same cybercriminals who used the SambaCry exploit to deliver a cryptocurrency miner  [Read More]
Intro.8: A piece of Linux malware dubbed MulDrop targets Raspberry Pi devices and abuses them for cryptocurrency mining  [Read More]
Intro.9: A 41-year-old Russian national has pleaded guilty over his role in a scheme involving the Ebury Linux botnet  [Read More]
Intro.10: A new Windows variant of Mirai is written in C++ and appears capable of performing various nefarious operations, one of which involves the spreading of the Mirai botnet to Linux-based devices.  [Read More]
Intro.11: The destructive KillDisk malware previously associated with attacks targeting industrial firms, was recently observed infecting Linux machines as well, ESET security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.12: Rakos malware is targeting embedded Linux systems and can provide attackers with full control over the infected devices, ESET security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.13: A newly observed Linux backdoor Trojan can perform its nefarious activities without root access, by using the privileges of the current user, Doctor Web security researchers have discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.14: A new piece of malware called FairWare is targeting Linux servers and deleting web folders, while "offering" to restore access to encrypted files for a ransom of 2 Bitcoins.  [Read More]
Intro.15: A newly observed Linux Trojan is capable of self-spreading through infected websites and can recruit the infected machines into a peer-to-peer (P2P) botnet, Doctor Web researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.16: A new piece of malware is targeting embedded systems with the mission to compromise and make them part of a botnet, ESET security researchers have discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.17: A hacker has breached the official Linux Mint website and forum. An ISO has been replaced with a backdoored version and forum user details have been offered for sale  [Read More]
Intro.18: Researchers at Palo Alto Networks have performed an in-depth analysis of Fysbis, the preferred Linux malware used by the Pawn Storm threat group.  [Read More]
Intro.19: Researchers at Kaspersky Lab have discovered a Linux backdoor that has been migrated to Windows and added a series of new capabilities.  [Read More]
Intro.20: A new Trojan targeting Linux system has been discovered to engage into versatile malicious activity, according to researchers from security firm Dr.Web.  [Read More]
Intro.21: Roughly 2,600 websites have been infected with the recently discovered Linux encryption ransomware Linux.Encoder1.  [Read More]
Intro.22: Predictable encryption keys allow victims of Linux.Encoder1 ransomware to recover files held for ransom. Bitdefender releases recovery tool.  [Read More]
Intro.23: A new file-encrypting ransomware has been spotted targeting Linux users, particularly webmasters.  [Read More]
Intro.24: Akamai said a botnet using the XOR DDoS Trojan is now capable of launching 150+ gigabit-per-second (Gbps) DDoS attacks.  [Read More]
Intro.25: Linux Australia server hacked. The attackers set up a botnet C&C server and they might have stolen the personal details of conference attendees.  [Read More]
Intro.26: XOR.DDoS is a piece of malware that's used by Chinese threat actors to launch DDoS attacks from Linux and other types of systems.  [Read More]

Intro.29: Security researchers have discovered that a piece of malware designed to run on Linux computers has been ported by its creators to Windows.  [Read More]
